source: Slide 1 - Cloud and Fog Scheduling - I
question: Which of the following best defines a 'cloud' according to the provided material?
options: A local network of physical servers with fixed resource allocation.
A collection of interconnected and virtualized computers presented as unified computing resources based on SLAs.
A single supercomputer that provides static services to all users regardless of negotiation.
A decentralized set of sensors and controllers that operate independently of data centers.
correct_answers: A collection of interconnected and virtualized computers presented as unified computing resources based on SLAs.

source: Slide 4 - Cloud and Fog Scheduling - I
question: What is the primary aim of scheduling in a cloud environment?
options: Maximizing the number of physical machines used
High throughput with least execution time
Reducing the number of users connected to the network
Prioritizing hardware maintenance over task execution
correct_answers: High throughput with least execution time

source: Slide 5 - Cloud and Fog Scheduling - I
question: Which of the following are listed as goals of scheduling? (Select all that apply)
options: Improving load balance
Improving fairness for all tasks
Increasing the number of successfully completed tasks
Decreasing system throughput to save energy
correct_answers: Increasing the number of successfully completed tasks

source: Slide 5 - Cloud and Fog Scheduling - I
question: Which type of scheduling involves grouping tasks before sending them to resources, also known as 'mapping events'?
options: Immediate scheduling
Batch scheduling
Static scheduling
Preemptive scheduling

source: Slide 5 - Cloud and Fog Scheduling - I
question: Static scheduling is characterized by which of the following?
options: It requires prior information of the global state of the system.
It takes into account the current real-time state of VMs.
It is more complex than dynamic scheduling.
It re-allocates tasks during execution to improve speed.
correct_answers: It requires prior information of the global state of the system.

source: Slide 6 - Cloud and Fog Scheduling - I
question: Match the task scheduling type to its description.
options: Takes into account current state of VMs and distributes tasks according to capacity.
Task is interrupted during execution and can be moved to another resource.
VMs are not re-allocated to new tasks until the current task finishes.
Tasks are scheduled to VMs directly upon arrival.

correct_answers.A: Takes into account current state of VMs and distributes tasks according to capacity.
correct_answers.B: Task is interrupted during execution and can be moved to another resource.
correct_answers.C: VMs are not re-allocated to new tasks until the current task finishes.

source: Slide 6 - Cloud and Fog Scheduling - I

options: First Come First Serve and Prioritized Scheduling
Round Robin and Genetic Algorithms
Shortest Job First and Ant Colony Optimization
Dynamic Migration and Resource Monitoring
correct_answers: First Come First Serve and Prioritized Scheduling

source: Slide 7 - Cloud and Fog Scheduling - I
question: In workflow scheduling, workflows are usually defined as a DAG. What does DAG stand for and what do its components represent?
options: Directed Acyclic Graph; Nodes = tasks, Edges = flow
Distributed Access Gateway; Nodes = servers, Edges = data
Direct Allocation Grid; Nodes = users, Edges = priority
Dynamic Acyclic Group; Nodes = VMs, Edges = migration
correct_answers: Directed Acyclic Graph; Nodes = tasks, Edges = flow
